head.title: Enhanced Device Performances of MAFACsPb(IxBr1–x) Perovskite Solar Cells with Dual-Functional 2-Chloroethyl Acrylate Additives | ACS Applied Materials & Interfaces

meta.content: Enhanced Device Performances of MAFACsPb(IxBr1–x) Perovskite Solar Cells with Dual-Functional 2-Chloroethyl Acrylate Additives

Perovskite photovoltaics (PePVs) tend to suffer from a high density of defects that restrict the device in terms of performances and stability. Therefore, defect passivation and film-quality improvement of perovskite active layers are crucial for high-performance PePVs. In this work, 2-chloroethyl acrylate (CEA) with C═O and −Cl groups in Cs0.175FA0.750MA0.075Pb (I0.880Br0.120) precursor solutions is introduced as a novel bifunctional additive to act as both a defect passivator and perovskite-growth controller. With the aid of CEA, the perovskite crystallinity and average grain size are improved, and perovskite defects are effectively reduced, thus increasing the representative efficiency (PCE = 19.32%). PePVs with CEA also maintain their initial efficiency of 85% even after about 500 h under air conditions with a humidity of 40 ± 5%. As a result, this study proves that the novel additive CEA can produce higher PePV efficiency and more stable devices.

div.p:
Perovskite photovoltaics (PePVs) tend to suffer from a high density of defects that restrict the device in terms of performances and stability. Therefore, defect passivation and film-quality improvement of perovskite active layers are crucial for high-performance PePVs. In this work, 2-chloroethyl acrylate (CEA) with C═O and −Cl groups in Cs
0.175
FA
0.750
MA
0.075
Pb (I
0.880
Br
0.120
) precursor solutions is introduced as a novel bifunctional additive to act as both a defect passivator and perovskite-growth controller. With the aid of CEA, the perovskite crystallinity and average grain size are improved, and perovskite defects are effectively reduced, thus increasing the representative efficiency (PCE = 19.32%). PePVs with CEA also maintain their initial efficiency of 85% even after about 500 h under air conditions with a humidity of 40 ± 5%. As a result, this study proves that the novel additive CEA can produce higher PePV efficiency and more stable devices.

div.span: KEYWORDS:
ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
Organic–inorganic metal halide perovskites with excellent material properties are in the spotlight because of their cost-efficient manufacturing, simplified process steps, and remarkable photoelectric conversion efficiency.
(1−6)
Perovskite-based photovoltaics (PePVs) recently overcame ∼25% with the aid of material design, interface modification, and film fabrication method.
(3−6)
The perovskite’s structure is ABX
3
(A and B = cations and X = anions).
(4)
Among them, perovskite materials based on MAPbI
3
are most commonly used; however, these are highly dependent on environmental influences such as moisture, oxygen, and heat stress, which greatly limit the commercialization of solar cells.
(5,6)
To this end, “triple cation” (Cs/MA/FA) can be an alternative because it possesses great stability along with high absorption, especially, a Cs(FAPbI
3
)
1–
X
(MAPbBr
3
)
X
-based perovskite system exhibits high efficiency and phase stability because of its reduced band gap and suppressed yellow phase impurities.
(7−9)

Despite many efforts, unfortunately, perovskite films containing polycrystalline materials are primarily based on solution-processing methods, and a large amount of defects resulting from the rapid crystal growth of the film are still a problem for high-performance devices.
(10−12)
Because these defects not only act as recombination centers but also allow the oxygen and moisture to penetrate very easily into the perovskite layer, which can break down cell performance,
(13,14)
it is quite important to manufacture high-quality, defect-free perovskite films in order to implement high-efficiency PePVs. For this purpose, various additive studies on coordinate or ion bond-based electrostatic interaction have been attempted mostly for defect passivation and high-quality film formation.
(15−18)
For example, negatively charged defects (e.g., lead halide (Pb–I)-based antisite, undercoordinated I
–
ions, etc.) can be passivated by introducing Lewis acid such as PCBM.
(19)
Also, small-molecule Lewis bases with lone pair electrons on sulfur (S) or nitrogen (N),
(14)
organic dyes,
(20)
and Lewis base polymers
(21,22)
can passivate perovskite defects in combination with undercoordinated Pb
2+
ions. To produce more uniform and perfect perovskite films without defects, additives having oxygen functional groups (C═O and P═O) and hydroxyl groups (−OH) were also reported.
(15,23−25)
In particular, the C═O functional group has been proven to retard crystal growth for better perovskite film formation and to passivate perovskite defects by forming a Lewis adduct with Pb
2+
.
(26)
Similarly, −Cl is known to be an effective additive to passivate perovskite defects (Pb–I antisite, Pb
2+
, and halide vacancies) and also to improve the film morphology by forming the Cl-containing intermediate phase to control the film crystallization rate.
(27−31)
These Cl functions could be because −Cl has higher electronegativity than the I
–
ion, and the addition of −Cl can supplement the unstable crystal structure and defect state caused by weak bonding between the perovskite precursor and I
–
ion.
(27,28,31)
Furthermore, as more advanced approaches, a bifunctional group-based additive has been recently introduced; ethylamine alcohol chlorides (EA•HCl) with −OH and NH
3
+
functional groups and hydroxylamine hydrochloride (HaHc) with −Cl and −OH groups were introduced and showed in a variety of effect on perovskite growth control, surface passivation, and PePV performance.
(32,33)
Zheng et al. also introduced the 3-(decyldimethylammonio)-propanesulfonate inner salt (DPSI)-containing quaternary ammonium groups and sulfone groups in inverted PePVs, which achieved a PCE of 21.1% because of better perovskite crystallization and both positively and negatively charged defect passivation.
(34)
However, although these bifunctional additive approaches showed the feasibility of simultaneously realizing defect passivation and perovskite growth control, most of this additive engineering still focuses on one functional additive, and reports on multifunctional additives are rare.
(32−35)
More importantly, although previous studies have also found that each C═O- or −Cl-containing additive can play key roles as perovskite growth-controlling and defect-passivating agent, there has been no reports on additive approaches containing both C═O and −Cl for PePV-performance enhancement.

Herein, we investigated a novel additive material, 2-chloroethyl acrylate (CEA) including C═O and −Cl (CEA), in a Cs
0.175
FA
0.750
MA
0.075
Pb(I
0.880
Br
0.120
) precursor for perovskite-film quality and defect passivation improvement. Comprehensive device and film analyses revealed that the C═O and −Cl of CEA not only increase the grain size and reduce grain boundaries (GBs) by controlling the perovskite crystal growth but also passivate defects in the perovskite surface and GB through strong interaction with the perovskite precursor species. Eventually, with CEA, the PePV displayed an enhanced efficiency of 19.32% compared to the PePV without CEA (17.33%), and the PePV with CEA also showed improved device stability. This approach to the use of bifunctional additives will provide a viable direction for efficiently producing both perovskite crystal growth control and defect passivation to contribute to the development of high-functioning PePVs.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
All substances and solvents used in the current experiment were purchased in accordance with our formerly reports.
(16,36)
Two types of perovskite precursor solutions were prepared for comparison of the perovskite layer. To prepare a perovskite precursor with the additive, CEA (Sigma-Aldrich) was mixed into the prepared pristine solution (ν/ν = 1, 3, and 5:100). For a pristine perovskite precursor solution, we referenced the previously reported synthetic method. Patterned ITO glass (15 mm × 15 mm, AMG-Tech) was cleaned and dried successively in the same way as the previous process.
(16,36)
Before coating HTL, the surface of the ITO was UV–Ozone plasma-treated (for up to 30 min). The HTL was deposited with 40 μL of nickel nanoparticle dispersion solution (NiO NPs, NICT-7, 1-Material) on ITO glass (3000 rpm, 40 s) and annealed in air (350 °C, 30 min). A total of 35 μL of perovskite precursor solution with and without CEA was coated onto a uniform NiO (NPs) layer by a two-step process (500 rpm for 5 s and 5000 rpm for 45 s). At ∼ 15 s after the second coating process begins, CB was dropped all at once on the rotating perovskite film within 2 s and then the heat process was performed (100 °C, 10 min).
(16,36)
For ETL coating, 20 μL of PCBM was coated on finished perovskite films and then annealed in a glovebox (100 °C, 10 min). Subsequently, ZnO (NPs) solution was deposited on the PCBM layer (8000 rpm, 40 s) and then annealed in air (100 °C, 10 min). Finally, the Ag electrode was deposited through a thermal evaporation equipment (10
–6
Torr) using an oval-shaped metal shadow mask (active area 0.0464 cm
2
).
(16,36)
The more detailed preparations of all layers are consistent with previously employed methods.
(16,36)
The V
OC
dependence on light intensity was obtained using a set of filter wheel (Newport) with neutral density (ND). The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectrum was recorded under the 4000–1000 cm
–1
range using a PerkinElmer (Frontier). The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) was characterized using a K-Alpha spectrometer. In addition to this, other general photovoltaic characteristics [e.g.,
J
–
V
results of PePVs, field emission scanning electron microscopy (FE-SEM), QE, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transient photocurrent (TPC), PL, Photo-CELIV, etc.] were estimated using the same system as previously reported.
(16,36,39)

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div:
An inverted planar perovskite photovoltaic covered in this investigation was structured, as shown in
Figure
1
, and the perovskite active layer was built using a precursor solution containing a triple cation with or without CEA possessing C═O and −Cl as an additive. First, to find out about the CEA effect as additives and fix the optimal content of additives, PePVs were prepared by adding various concentrations (1, 3, and 5 vol %) of CEA to the perovskite precursors. The detailed statistical data and photovoltaic parameter values were recorded and are shown in
Figure S1 and Table S1
. With CEA, all photovoltaic characteristics (e.g.,
V
OC
,
J
SC
, FF, and PCE) were largely enhanced. In particular, with increasing concentrations of CEA from 0 to 3 vol %, the PePV efficiencies were continuously improved. However, beyond 3 vol %, the cell performances decreased to 18.17% probably because of the additive’s insulating properties.
(37)
Consequently, the 3 vol % CEA produced the most enhanced photovoltaic characteristics in PePVs.

div.p: Figure 1. Schematic diagram of the PePV architecture and CEA additive’s molecular structure used in this work.

div.div:
In order to further comparatively study cell-performance changes with regard to the use of CEA, we performed statistical analyses of PePVs with or without 3 vol % CEA.
Figure
2
a shows a histogram with a Gaussian distribution of the PCE obtained from 40 devices with or without CEA. Devices manufactured without CEA showed a poor device performance from 15.42 to 17.92% (average 17.47 ± 0.234%), while devices with CEA have increased efficiencies with more than 19% (average 19.30 ± 0.196%) and improved reproducibility with a narrow distribution.
Figure
2
b shows a representative power curve, and
Table
1
details PePV characteristics. CEA-based PePV clearly showed higher performances than the device manufactured without CEA: When the CEA was added into a perovskite precursor, the device showed improved performance with an efficiency of 19.32% while PePV without CEA obtained an efficiency of 17.33%. This cell-efficiency improvement was further confirmed by QE
external
for PePVs with/without CEA, as indicated by
Figure
2
c. The
J
sc
values evaluated from the QE
external
spectrum of PePVs with and without CEA were 20.96 and 19.78 mA cm
–2
, respectively. Moreover, the PePV with CEA showed only small deviations between
J
SC
values in QE
external
and
J
SC
values in the
J
–
V
data with less than ∼ 4–5% mismatch, indicating a reliable device evaluation.
(38)
More importantly, the perovskite device with CEA exhibits enhanced light-harvesting capacity in overall spectral ranges. Furthermore, the QE
internal
determined by dividing QE
external
by reflective absorption is close to 100%, as shown in
Figure S2
, and the QE
external
and QE
internal
improvement ratios for CEA-based PePVs are nearly identical to 1.061 and 1.056, respectively, which can confirm that the PePV-efficiency improvement obtained with CEA is largely attributed to the enhanced charge extraction–transport properties.
(39,40)

div.p:
Figure 2. (a) PCE histogram of PePVs with/without CEA and Gaussian distribution curves. (b) Representative power curves for PePVs with/without CEA. (c) QE
external
and integrated
J
SC
of representative PePVs with/without CEA.

div.div: Table 1. Photovoltaic Performance Results of Representative PePVs with/without CEA

To understand how CEA affected the morphological and crystallographic characterizations of perovskite films and PePV performances, we performed various optoelectronic and morphological analyses. In surface images of SEM (
Figure
3
a), a CEA-free perovskite thin film showed randomly distributed small grains (an average of 200 nm), while the perovskite thin film containing CEA showed enlarged grains (an average of 300 nm) with narrow grain-size distribution and uniform and dense surface morphology. In addition, in cross-sectional images, the perovskite film thickness with and without CEA changed little to around 340 nm. However, the perovskite grain size showed a conspicuous difference between the two thin films; perovskite with CEA showed a single interface of large grains oriented perpendicular to a substrate, while perovskite without CEA showed multiple interfaces with small grains. Also, in the AFM top-view topography (
Figure. S3
), CEA produced a smoother perovskite film with 14.63 nm rms compared to the pristine film with 26.98 nm rms. From these SEM and AFM images, it was confirmed that the CEA addition can provide more desirable perovskite films. Furthermore, XRD was analyzed for confirming CEA effects on perovskite crystallization, and representative diffraction peaks of perovskite with and without CEA were shown at 14.0°, 28.1°, and 31.5°, respectively (
Figure
3
b).
(41)
For perovskite with CEA, the intensity of the main peak oriented at the (110) plane was increased, and with the CEA, the FWHM was reduced up to 0.24 (from 0.27), indicating that CEA can promote more preferred oriented crystal growth with enhanced crystallinity and enlarged grains.
(41,42)
To verify the influence of CEA on the optical factors and photocarrier dynamics, the light absorption and charge-carrier process were evaluated using optical equipments. In
Figure S4
, both devices without and with CEA showed a similar absorption spectrum over the entire visible range. Therefore, the enhanced solar cell performance by adding CEA can be associated with enhanced charge extraction-transport properties rather than photoabsorption properties, and it matches well with the QE
external
and QE
internal
data. In PL result (
Figure
3
c), the perovskite film without CEA had a peak at 782 nm, whereas the peak of the perovskite film with CEA showed a lower shift from 782 to 775 nm. Besides, the PL peak intensity of perovskite films with CEA was about two times stronger when compared to that of the perovskite film without CEA. This change in the PL peak means that the CEA introduced into the perovskite can manufacture a higher-quality photoactive film with the passivation or suppression of the defect states and nonradioactive recombination sites to produce higher cell efficiency.
(18,43,44)
More importantly, these overall results suggest that the CEA can help to make the perovskite film with larger grains, better crystallinity, and more suppressed recombination for charge-extraction and -transport improvement. In addition, it is also confirmed that the CEA-induced perovskite-film changes can affect the overall enhanced PePV performances.

div.p: Figure 3. (a) SEM (surface and cross-sectional) images of perovskites with/without CEA and grain-size distribution. (b) XRD diffraction pattern and (c) PL spectrum of perovskites with/without CEA.

div.div:
To further study the association between CEA-induced film condition and device performance, we measured the charge-transfer and recombination kinetics in PePVs with and without CEA. Generally, evidence for reduced defects in the PePV device can be explained from the relationship between light intensity and
V
OC
.
(45,46)
As the slope value
n
of
V
OC
dependence on light intensity is close to 1, it means an absence of trap-assisted recombination in devices.
(45−47)
The n of the device with CEA exhibits a weaker
V
OC
light intensity dependence (1.36 kT/q) than
n
(1.51 kT/q) of the device without CEA (
Figure
4
a). The reduced slope in CEA-based PePV demonstrates that charge recombination and trap states are effectively reduced using CEA, leading to
V
OC
and PCE improvement.
(45−47)
As shown in
Figure
4
b, in order to further confirm the trap state density in PePV with and without CEA, a space-charging limiting current (SCLC) measurement was performed using a hole-only device. The trap state density was decided using the equation
(48)
(1)
Here ε = 28.8 (dielectric constants of CsPbMABrI
3
), ε
0
= 8.85 × 10
–12
F m
–1
, and
L
is the thickness of the perovskite film.
(10,48,49)
The trap-filled limit voltage (
V
TFL
) of PePV without/with CEA was obtained as 0.72 and 0.42 V, respectively, and PePV with CEA showed a lower defect density (1.60 × 10
16
cm
–3
) compared to the PePV without CEA (2.65 × 10
16
cm
–3
), indicating that CEA can effectively passivate defects and decrease the trap density of perovskites.
(48,49)
For better comparative observation, the charge-transport behavior in PePVs with and without CEA under actual working conditions was investigated by photo-CELIV, one of the methods for quantitatively measuring the mobilities of photogenerated charge carriers.
(50)
Figure
4
c represents the photo-CELIV signal for PePVs with and without CEA, and the charge carrier mobility of PePVs with CEA (6.68 × 10
–3
cm
2
V
–1
s
–1
) is higher than that of PePVs without CEA (5.14 × 10
–3
cm
2
V
–1
s
–1
), suggesting that the CEA-based PePV can provide more enhanced charge transport/extraction abilities than the PePV without CEA.
(50,51)
In addition, the TPC decay time for the CEA-based PePV was shorter than the pristine devices; as shown in
Figure
4
d, devices with CEA and without CEA showed 0.45 and 1.35 μs TPC decay time, respectively, thus confirming that a more effective charge transport is possible in the CEA-based PePV.
(18,44)
More notably, these comprehensive observations shown in
Figure
4
support that the CEA-induced, better device performances could be caused by the improved charge transport behavior and suppressed trap-assisted recombination to be achieved with the CEA-induced perovskite-film changes.

div.p:
Figure 4. (a) Light intensity vs
V
OC
for PePVs with/without CEA. (b) Dark curves of PePVs with/without CEA (hole-only devices), (c) photo-CELIV current transits, and (d) TPC of PePVs with/without CEA.

div.div:
In order to understand how CEA induces favorable changes in perovskite films and PePV performance, we measured the FTIR of CEA and solvents with or without the PbI
2
perovskite precursor, as shown in
Figures
5
a and
S5
. In general, PbI
2
, Lewis acid, is well-known to form adducts by interaction with Lewis bases containing sulfur, nitrogen, and oxygen functional groups. Thus, coordination bonds of PbI
2
species with polar solvents (e.g., DMF and DMSO) are employed to identify the coordination of ions and molecules in the perovskite solution, which can be described by C═O and S═O frequency shift.
(52−54)
Herein, FTIR studies of the solvents and PbI
2
were performed (
Figure S5
). The vibration associated with C═O bonding by DMF and S═O bonding by DMSO in the solvent appeared at 1651 cm
–1
and 1022 cm
–1
, respectively; however, when PbI
2
was added, these original peaks shifted to the lower wavenumber. The lowered peak frequency indicates that the PbI
2
·solvent intermediate phase was formed because of the interplay between the polar solvent and Lewis acid PbI
2
, and the bond strength between carbon or sulfur and oxygen in the solvent was weakened as a result of the intermediate adducts.
(54−56)
Similarly, to confirm the coordination interaction between the PbI
2
precursor and additive (CEA), we further studied the FTIR and focused on the change in the C═O peak of CEA. As shown in
Figure
5
a, the C═O functional group peak of CEA was monitored at 1720 cm
–1
, and with PbI
2
, the C═O characteristic peak of CEA shifted to a lower frequency. Through this, it was found that the C═O of CEA can interact with PbI
2
, and the new intermediate phase (PbI
2
·CEA) can be formed.
(23,57−59)
This intermediate phases that delay the formation of perovskite can help to adjust the perovskite-crystallization kinetics during film processing and to provide better crystallization and grain size.
(60,61)
In addition, considering that the C═O group has already been reported as a functional group capable of passivating defects on the perovskite film by providing an electron pair from the C═O double bond to the undercoordinated Pb
2+
, if the additive still existed after fully solid-state perovskite-film formation, it was believed that C═O of CEA can passivate defects such as undercoordinated Pb
2+
.
(23,62)
In addition, as mentioned earlier, it is known that the additive containing Cl can also promote growth of the grain size by controlling the crystallization rate.
(33,63,64)
Therefore, for CEA having both C═O and Cl, it can be regarded as forming the intermediate phase and delaying the crystallization rate as reported above, which can be supported by the enlarged grain size of perovskite with CEA, as shown in
Figure
3
. XPS exploration was implemented to better find out the change in chemical interaction between the CEA and perovskite interface.
Figure
5
b and c shows the Pb 4f and I 3d spectrum of perovskite with and without CEA, respectively. The binding energies of Pb and I of perovskite with CEA indicated higher binding energies than perovskite without CEA. This result could be due to the facts that C═O can passivate defects such as undercoordinated Pb
2+
and Cl can passivate undercoordinated Pb
2+
ions, halide vacancies, and Pb–I antisites by stronger Pb–Cl bonds than Pb–I bonds.
(27−31,65)
More importantly, the XPS peak shift suggests an electronic passivation of perovskite by CEA,
(18,32,48,66,67)
which can provide lower trap-state density and can interfere with the movement of ions, thereby preventing the corrosion of the perovskite layer and the generation of charge recombination. In addition, as shown in
Figure S6
, the EDS data showed well-distributed CEA in solid-state perovskite films and also continued the CEA presence, which is thus well supporting current XPS results that can confirm defect passivation because of the residual CEA. Furthermore, taken together with overall results, it can be confirmed that the CEA can serve as dual-functional additives for perovskite growth controller and defect passivator for PePV-efficiency improvement.

div.p:
Figure 5. (a) FTIR spectra of CEA with/without PbI
2
. (b) Pb and (c) I peaks in XPS spectra of the perovskite film with/without CEA.

div.div:
Because the PePV’s stability test is also one of the critical control elements for commercialization, we investigated the stability of the CEA-based PePV. To do this, PePVs were stored in air for ∼500 h after fabrication. The stability of PePV with or without CEA was monitored under identical conditions (25 °C, 40 ± 5% RH) according to the ISOS-D-1 protocol without encapsulation
,
(68)
and the relative values are presented in
Figure
6
. The PCE of the PePV without CEA quickly dropped and approached ∼0% of its initial PCE after ∼500 h, and other photovoltaic parameters showed similar trends and significant reduction under the same conditions. In contrast, the PePV with CEA maintained 85% of the initial PCE after ∼500 h. This improved atmospheric stability may be due to the high-quality film obtained with CEA addition. More importantly, these results clearly demonstrate that PePVs prepared using CEA show better device stability and moisture resistance as well as more enhanced cell efficiency.

div.p: Figure 6. Normalized parameter variation in PePVs with/without CEA for 500 h under ambient air storage.

div.span: ARTICLE SECTIONS

div.div: In summary, we investigated a novel dual-functioning additive, CEA, which contains C═O and −Cl, for better perovskite film production, and we methodically studied the effects of CEA on the perovskite film and also carefully monitored the characteristics of the CEA-based PePVs. Through inclusive device and film analyses, we discovered that the CEA addition leads to improved perovskite-film quality, reduced trap states, and diminished nonradiative charge carrier recombination for better carrier transport and device efficiency. The FTIR and XPS measurements revealed that the CEA can form an intermediate phase with perovskite precursors to delay the crystallization process of perovskite for larger grain formation. In addition, it was shown that the CEA can passivate the perovskite films, thus confirming that the newly introduced CEA can act efficiently as a dual-function additive for both better perovskite-growth formation and perovskite-defect passivation. Consequently, the CEA-based PePV displayed an efficiency of up to 19.32%. Furthermore, the CEA produced better long-term stability in PePVs, maintaining ∼85% PCE of their initial performance after ∼500 h ambient exposure.

The energy costs assocd. with sepg. tightly bound excitons (photoinduced electron-hole pairs) and extg. free charges from highly disordered low-mobility networks represent fundamental losses for many low-cost photovoltaic technologies. A low-cost, soln.-processable solar cell is reported, based on a highly cryst. perovskite absorber with intense visible to near-IR absorptivity, that has a power conversion efficiency of 10.9% in a single-junction device under simulated full sunlight. This "meso-superstructured solar cell" exhibits exceptionally few fundamental energy losses; it can generate open-circuit photovoltages of more than 1.1 V, despite the relatively narrow absorber band gap of 1.55 eV. The functionality arises from the use of mesoporous alumina as an inert scaffold that structures the absorber and forces electrons to reside in and be transported through the perovskite.

The band gap of formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI3) perovskites allows broader absorption of the solar spectrum relative to conventional methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3). Because the optoelectronic properties of perovskite films are closely related to film quality, deposition of dense and uniform films is crucial for fabricating high-performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs). An approach is reported for depositing high-quality FAPbI3 films, involving FAPbI3 crystn. by the direct intramol. exchange of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) mols. intercalated in PbI2 with formamidinium iodide. This process produces FAPbI3 films with (111)-preferred crystallog. orientation, large-grained dense microstructures, and flat surfaces without residual PbI2. Using films prepd. by this technique, the FAPbI3-based PSCs are fabricated with max. power conversion efficiency greater than 20%.

Here, first-principles d. functional theory calcns. are presented which reveal how water incorporation in hybrid halide perovskite [CH3NH3]PbI3 (MAPbI3) catalyzes the phase transition to the ([CH3NH3]PbI3.H2O edge-sharing) monohydrate (colorless) phase, eliminating its favorable photovoltaic properties. First, fundamental chem. and electrostatic interactions between water and each component of MAPbI3 are analyzed, demonstrating their dependence on water concn. Second, the energetics of incorporated water is explored, leading to the discovery of spontaneous phase segregation into dry regions and regions with more than one water per formula unit-termed the "super-hydrous state.". Third, the properties of the super-hydrous state are analyzed, including the acceleration of octahedron breaking and rearrangement by the high water d. This reveals the phase transformation to be a bulk process, initiated at the super-hydrous regions. This paper concludes with a discussion of how this super-hydrous model explains disparate recent exptl. observations concerning the water-induced transition from (black) perovskite to edge-sharing PbI2 (yellow) phase. Today's best perovskite solar cells use a mixt. of formamidinium and methylammonium as the monovalent cations. With the addn. of inorg. cesium, the resulting triple cation perovskite compns. are thermally more stable, contain less phase impurities and are less sensitive to processing conditions. This enables more reproducible device performances to reach a stabilized power output of 21.1% and ∼18% after 250 h under operational conditions. These properties are key for the industrialization of perovskite photovoltaics.

Towards increasing the stability of perovskite solar cells, the addn. of Cs+ is found to be a rational approach. Recently triple cation based perovskite solar cells were found to be more effective in terms of stability and efficiency. Heretofore they were unexplored, so the Cs/MA/FA (cesium/methyl ammonium/formamidinium) cation based perovskites is probed by XPS and correlated their compositional features with their solar cell performances. The Cs+ content was found to be optimum at 5%, when incorporated in the (MA0.15FA0.85)Pb(I0.85Br0.15)3 lattice, because the corresponding device yielded the highest fill factor compared to the perovskite without Cs+ and with 10% Cs+. XPS studies distinctly reveal how Cs+ aids in maintaining the expected stoichiometric ratios of I:Pb2+, I:N and Br:Pb2+ in the perovskites, and how the valence band (VB) edge is dependent on the Cs+ proportion, which in turn governs the open circuit voltage. Even at a low content of 5%, Cs+ resides deep within the absorber layer, and ensures min. distortion of the VB level (compared to 0% and 10% Cs+ perovskites) upon Ar+ sputtering, thus allowing the formation of a stable robust material that delivers excellent solar cell response. This study which brings out the role of Cs+ is anticipated to be of paramount significance to further engineer the compn. and improve device performances.

Long, balanced electron and hole diffusion lengths greater than 100 nm in the polycryst. organolead trihalide compd. CH3NH3PbI3 are crit. for highly efficient perovskite solar cells. We found that the diffusion lengths in CH3NH3PbI3 single crystals grown by a soln.-growth method can exceed 175 μm under 1 sun (100 mW cm-2) illumination and exceed 3 mm under weak light for both electrons and holes. The internal quantum efficiencies approach 100% in 3-mm-thick single-crystal perovskite solar cells under weak light. These long diffusion lengths result from greater carrier mobility, longer lifetime, and much smaller trap densities in the single crystals than in polycryst. thin films. The long carrier diffusion lengths enabled the use of CH3NH3PbI3 in radiation sensing and energy harvesting through the gammavoltaic effect, with an efficiency of 3.9% measured with an intense cesium-137 source.

The soln. processing of polycryst. perovskite films introduces trap states that can adversely affect their optoelectronic properties. Motivated by the use of small-mol. surfactants to improve the optoelectronic performance of perovskites, we demonstrate the use of polymerswith coordinating groups to improve the performance of solutionprocessed semiconductor films. The use of these polymer modifiers results in amarked change in the electronic properties of the films, asmeasured by both carrier dynamics and overall device performance. The devices grown with the polymer poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PVP) show significantly enhanced power conversion efficiency from 16.9 ± 0.7% to 18.8 ± 0.8% (champion efficiency, 20.2%) from a reverse scan and stabilized champion efficiency from 17.5 to 19.1% [under a bias of 0.94 V and AM (air mass) 1.5-G, 1-sun illumination over 30 min] compared to controls without any passivation. Treating the perovskite filmwith PVP enables a VOC of up to 1.16 V,which is among the best reported for a CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite solar cell and one of the lowest voltage deficits reported for any perovskite to date. In addn., perovskite solar cells treated with PVP show a long shelf lifetime of up to 90 days (retaining 85% of the initial efficiency) and increased by a factor of more than 20 compared to those without any polymer (degrading to 85% after ∼4 days). Our work opens up a new class of chem. additives for improving perovskite performance and should pave the way toward improving perovskite solar cells for high efficiency and stability.

We study the effects of a series of post-deposition ligand treatments on the photoluminescence (PL) of polycryst. methylammonium lead triiodide perovskite thin films. We show that a variety of Lewis bases can improve the bulk PL quantum efficiency (PLQE) and extend the av. PL lifetime, 〈τ〉, with large enhancements concd. at grain boundaries. Notably, we demonstrate thin-film PLQE as high as 35 ± 1% and 〈τ〉 as long as 8.82 ± 0.03 μs at solar equiv. carrier densities using tri-n-octylphosphine oxide-treated films. Using glow discharge optical emission spectroscopy and NMR spectroscopy, we show that the ligands are incorporated primarily at the film surface and are acting as electron donors. These results indicate it is possible to obtain thin-film PL lifetime and PLQE values that are comparable to those from single crystals by control over surface chem.

Fast oxygen diffusion and iodide defects mediate oxygen-induced degradation of perovskite solar cells
Aristidou Nicholas; Sanchez-Molina Irene; Bu Xiangnan; Kosco Jan; Haque Saif A; Eames Christopher; Islam M Saiful
Nature communications
(
2017
),

.
Methylammonium lead halide perovskites are attracting intense interest as promising materials for next-generation solar cells, but serious issues related to long-term stability need to be addressed. Perovskite films based on CH3NH3PbI3 undergo rapid degradation when exposed to oxygen and light. Here, we report mechanistic insights into this oxygen-induced photodegradation from a range of experimental and computational techniques. We find fast oxygen diffusion into CH3NH3PbI3 films is accompanied by photo-induced formation of highly reactive superoxide species. Perovskite films composed of small crystallites show higher yields of superoxide and lower stability. Ab initio simulations indicate that iodide vacancies are the preferred sites in mediating the photo-induced formation of superoxide species from oxygen. Thin-film passivation with iodide salts is shown to enhance film and device stability. The understanding of degradation phenomena gained from this study is important for the future design and optimization of stable perovskite solar cells.

Org.-inorg. metal halide perovskites have recently emerged as a top contender to be used as an absorber material in highly efficient, low-cost photovoltaic devices. Soln.-processed semiconductors tend to have a high d. of defect states and exhibit a large degree of electronic disorder. Perovskites appear to go against this trend, and despite relatively little knowledge of the impact of electronic defects, certified solar-to-elec. power conversion efficiencies of up to 17.9% have been achieved. Here, through treatment of the crystal surfaces with the Lewis bases thiophene and pyridine, the authors demonstrate significantly reduced nonradiative electron-hole recombination within the MeNH3PbI3-xClx perovskite, achieving photoluminescence lifetimes which are enhanced by nearly an order of magnitude, up to 2 μs. Probably this is due to the electronic passivation of under-coordinated Pb atoms within the crystal. Through this method of Lewis base passivation, the authors achieve power conversion efficiencies for soln.-processed planar heterojunction solar cells enhanced from 13% for the untreated solar cells to 15.3% and 16.5% for the thiophene and pyridine-treated solar cells, resp.

A review. All highly-efficient org.-inorg. halide perovskite (OIHP) solar cells to date are made of polycryst. perovskite films which contain a high d. of defects, including point and extended imperfections. The imperfections in OIHP materials play an important role in the process of charge recombination and ion migration in perovskite solar cells (PSC), which heavily influences the resulting device energy conversion efficiency and stability. Here we review the recent advances in passivation of imperfections and suppressing ion migration to achieve improved efficiency and highly stable perovskite solar cells. Due to the ionic nature of OIHP materials, the defects in the photoactive films are inevitably elec. charged. The deep level traps induced by particular charged defects in OIHP films are major non-radiative recombination centers; passivation by coordinate bonding, ionic bonding, or chem. conversion have proven effective in mitigating the neg. impacts of these deep traps. Shallow level charge traps themselves may contribute little to non-radiative recombination, but the migration of charged shallow level traps in OIHP films results in unfavorable band bending, interfacial reactions, and phase segregation, influencing the carrier extn. efficiency. Finally, the impact of defects and ion migration on the stability of perovskite solar cells is described.

Imperfection originating from the ionic nature of org. inorg. hybrid perovskite (OIHP) is a major factor that degrades perovskite solar cells (PSCs) performance, and mitigating or removing it is essential for the implementation of high-performance PSCs. In this work, 2-hydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA), having both effective C=O and O-H functional groups, is introduced as a functional additive that suppress imperfections by to control the crystn. process and passivate them at the same time, and the role of each function groups have been systematically investigated. We have found that O-H functional groups of HEA strongly interacts with org. cations (i.e., MABr, FAI) to form more stable org. cation-HEA complex selectively, delaying the crystn. process of perovskite. As a result, HEA improves crystallinity and grain size of perovskite and reduces charge trapping d. by passivation and/or suppression of defect states. HEA raises av. cell-efficiency from 17.37% to 19.01% and the max. efficiency is reached to 21.01% for the inverted planar PSC. In addn., large-area (1.08 cm2) PSCs show an excellent efficiency of 20.40%, which is the highest efficiency in large-area inverted planar PSCs to date. PSCs with HEA also show long-term stability and better moisture resistance capabilities in ambient air conditions.

Organometal halide perovskite solar cell enjoys a rapid development in the last decade. However, the severe J-V hysteresis existed in perovskite solar cells leads to an over- or under-estn. of device efficiency. Herein, we introduce an ammonium salt as a new dopant of perovskite. As a result, the J-V hysteresis is almost eliminated, and a higher av. efficiency is obtained. Besides, the degrdn. under const. illumination in ambient atm. obsd. in control devices is greatly improved. Thin film characterizations reveal that the addn. of ammonium salt leads to smoother, more homogenous and better cryst. perovskite films, which exhibit more intense photoluminescence and a little longer fluorescent lifetime. Soln.-processed planar perovskite devices are highly desirable in a wide variety of optoelectronic applications; however, they are prone to hysteresis and current instabilities. Here we report the first perovskite-PCBM hybrid solid with significantly reduced hysteresis and recombination loss achieved in a single step. This new material displays an efficient elec. coupled microstructure: PCBM is homogeneously distributed throughout the film at perovskite grain boundaries. The PCBM passivates the key PbI3- antisite defects during the perovskite self-assembly, as revealed by theory and expt. Photoluminescence transient spectroscopy proves that the PCBM phase promotes electron extn. We showcase this mixed material in planar solar cells that feature low hysteresis and enhanced photovoltage. Using conductive AFM studies, we reveal the memristive properties of perovskite films. We close by positing that PCBM, by tying up both halide-rich antisites and unincorporated halides, reduces elec. field-induced anion migration that may give rise to hysteresis and unstable diode behavior.

Achieving long-term operational stability at a high efficiency level for perovskite solar cells is the most challenging issue toward commercialization of this emerging photovoltaic technol. Here, we investigated the cooperation of a Lewis base and a Lewis acid by combining com. bis-PCBM mixed isomers as the Lewis acid in the antisolvent and N-(4-bromophenyl)thiourea (BrPh-ThR) as the Lewis base in the perovskite soln. precursor. The combination of the Lewis base and the Lewis acid synergistically passivates Pb2+ and PbX3- antisite defects, enlarges the perovskite grain size, and improves charge-carrier sepn. and transport, leading to improved device efficiency from 19.3% to 21.7%. In addn., this Lewis base and acid combination also suppresses moisture incursion and passivates pinholes generated in the hole-transporting layer. The unsealed devices remained at 93% of the initial efficiency value in ambient air (10-20% relative humidity) after 3600 h at 20-25°C and dropped by 10% after 1500 h under continuous operation at 1-sun illumination and 55°C in nitrogen with max. power-point tracking.

Efficient wide-bandgap perovskite solar cells (PSCs) enable high-efficiency tandem photovoltaics when combined with crystalline silicon and other low-bandgap absorbers. However, wide-bandgap PSCs today exhibit performance far inferior to that of sub-1.6-eV bandgap PSCs due to their tendency to form a high density of deep traps. Here, we show that healing the deep traps in wide-bandgap perovskites-in effect, increasing the defect tolerance via cation engineering-enables further performance improvements in PSCs. We achieve a stabilized power conversion efficiency of 20.7% for 1.65-eV bandgap PSCs by incorporating dipolar cations, with a high open-circuit voltage of 1.22 V and a fill factor exceeding 80%. We also obtain a stabilized efficiency of 19.1% for 1.74-eV bandgap PSCs with a high open-circuit voltage of 1.25 V. From density functional theory calculations, we find that the presence and reorientation of the dipolar cation in mixed cation-halide perovskites heals the defects that introduce deep trap states.

The ionic defects at the surfaces and grain boundaries of org.-inorg. halide perovskite films are detrimental to both the efficiency and stability of perovskite solar cells. Here, we show that quaternary ammonium halides can effectively passivate ionic defects in several different types of hybrid perovskite with their neg.- and pos.-charged components. The efficient defect passivation reduces the charge trap d. and elongates the carrier recombination lifetime, which is supported by d.-function-theory calcn. The defect passivation reduces the open-circuit-voltage deficit of the p-i-n-structured device to 0.39 V, and boosts the efficiency to a certified value of 20.59 ± 0.45%. Our findings provide an avenue for defect passivation to further improve both the efficiency and stability of solar cells.

The role of Cl in halide hybrid perovskites CH3NH3PbI3(Cl) (MAPbI3(Cl)) on the augmentation of grain size is still unclear although many reports have referred to these phenomena. Herein, we synthesized MAPbI3(Cl) perovskite films by using excess MACl-containing precursors, which exhibited approximately an order of magnitude larger grain size with higher <110>-preferred orientation compared with that from stoichiometric precursors. Comprehensive mechanisms for the large grain evolution by Cl incorporation were elucidated in detail by correlating the changes in grain orientation, distribution of grain size, and the remaining Cl in the perovskite during thermal annealing. In the presence of Cl, <110>- and <001>-oriented grains grew faster than other grains at the initial stage of annealing. Further annealing led to the dissipation of Cl, resulting in the shrinkage of <001> grains while <110> grains continuously grew, as analyzed by x-ray rocking curve and diffraction. As a result of reduced grain boundaries and enhanced <110> texture, the trap density of perovskite solar cells diminished by ~10% by incorporating MACl in the precursor, resulting in a fill factor more than 80%.

Defects easily form in org.-inorg. hybrid perovskite (CH3NH3PbX3) absorber layers acting as recombination centers which reduce the performance of solar cells. Therefore, defect passivation is an efficient method to improve the performance of solar cells. Herein, ethylamine alc. chlorides is introduced into perovskite films to passivate defects. The hydroxyl group and ammonium group in ethylamine alc. chlorides can interact with halogen in MAPbIxCl3-x to form hydrogen bonds suppressing ion migration. In addn., the crosslinking neighboring perovskite grains through hydrogen bonds can also improve the perovskite grain size and film coverage. The data demonstrate that the obvious redn. of the defect concn. via defect passivation contributes to an enhancement of the open-circuit voltage from 0.87 V to 0.92 V and the device efficiency from 14.52% to 16.97%.

The present work provides a guideline for multifunctional additive engineering for the purpose of simultaneous achievement of a high PCE and long-term stability.

In this work, the quality is improved of the perovskite film using a functional additive in the perovskite antisolvent, which is known as antisolvent additive engineering (AAE). An AAE additive, 2-hydroxyethyl acrylate (HEA), that includes -OH and C=O functional groups is introduced into the antisolvent. Its effect on the perovskite film and devices is then systematically studied. Comprehensive analyses including cell performance, carrier transport dynamics, and perovskite surface and morphol. measurements were performed to prove that the HEA-based AAE leads to better perovskite films with a larger grain size and fewer perovskite defects and also to prove that this AAE approach is a promising way to obtain high-quality perovskite and corresponding high-efficiency perovskite solar cells. As a result, the facile AAE with HEA obtained a max. power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 20.46% and showed better stability, maintaining > 61% of its initial PCE after 96 days under ambient air conditions.

Soln. processable planar heterojunction perovskite solar cell is a very promising new technol. for low cost renewable energy. One of the most common cell structures is FTO/TiO2/CH3NH3PbI3-xClx/spiro-OMeTAD/Au. The main issues of this type of solar cell are the poor coverage and morphol. control of the perovskite CH3NH3PbI3-xClx film on TiO2. For the first time, we demonstrate that the problems can be easily resolved by using a polymer additive in perovskite precursor soln. during the film formation process. A 25% increase in power conversion efficiency at a value of 13.2% is achieved by adding 1 wt % of poly(ethylene glycol) in the perovskite layer using a 150°C processed TiO2 nanoparticle layer. The morphol. of this new perovskite was carefully studied by SEM, XRD, and AFM. The results reveal that the additive controls the size and aggregation of perovskite crystals and helps the formation of smooth film over TiO2 completely. Thus, the Voc and Jsc are greatly increased for a high efficiency solar cell. The amt. of additive is optimized at 1 wt % due to its insulating characteristics. This research provides a facile way to fabricate a high efficiency perovskite solar cell by the low temp. soln. process (<150°C), which has the advancement of conserving energy over the traditional high temp. sintering TiO2 compact layer device.

Two-dimensional (2D) org.-inorg. perovskites have recently emerged as one of the most important thin-film solar cell materials owing to their excellent environmental stability. The remaining major pitfall is their relatively poor photovoltaic performance in contrast to 3D perovskites. In this work we demonstrate cesium cation (Cs+) doped 2D (BA)2(MA)3Pb4I13 perovskite solar cells giving a power conversion efficiency (PCE) as high as 13.7%, the highest among the reported 2D devices, with excellent humidity resistance. The enhanced efficiency from 12.3% (without Cs+) to 13.7% (with 5% Cs+) is attributed to perfectly controlled crystal orientation, an increased grain size of the 2D planes, superior surface quality, reduced trap-state d., enhanced charge-carrier mobility and charge-transfer kinetics. Surprisingly, it is found that the Cs+ doping yields superior stability for the 2D perovskite solar cells when subjected to a high humidity environment without encapsulation. The device doped using 5% Cs+ degrades only ca. 10% after 1400 h of exposure in 30% relative humidity (RH), and exhibits significantly improved stability under heating and high moisture environments. Our results provide an important step toward air-stable and fully printable low dimensional perovskites as a next-generation renewable energy source.

Organometal halide perovskites have emerged as promising light absorbers for third-generation photovoltaics. Herein we developed a facile spray deposition process to prep. high-quality perovskite films without any post-annealing under ambient conditions with a high humidity of up to 50%. The as-prepd. perovskite films exhibit large grain sizes up to micrometers and full surface coverage. These desirable features significantly enhance the light harvesting efficiency and reduce charge recombination. Furthermore, the morphol. and film thickness can be easily controlled by varying the precursor concn. or scanning times during spray deposition. The as-fabricated planar heterojunction solar cells with an optimized perovskite film thickness exhibited a power conversion efficiency of ∼7.89%, which is expected to be further improved with the increase of substrate temp., the utilization of more compatible substrates, and the optimization of the hole-transport layer and device structure. This simple low-temp. manufg. process provides a novel strategy for the scalable and fast fabrication of high-quality absorber layers for efficient perovskite based solar cells. The film formation mechanism regarding the nucleation and growth of perovskite films with desirable morphol. is also discussed.

The large photocurrent hysteresis obsd. in many organometal trihalide perovskite solar cells has become a major hindrance impairing the ultimate performance and stability of these devices, while its origin was unknown. Here we demonstrate the trap states on the surface and grain boundaries of the perovskite materials to be the origin of photocurrent hysteresis and that the fullerene layers deposited on perovskites can effectively passivate these charge trap states and eliminate the notorious photocurrent hysteresis. Fullerenes deposited on the top of the perovskites reduce the trap d. by two orders of magnitude and double the power conversion efficiency of CH3NH3PbI3 solar cells. The elucidation of the origin of photocurrent hysteresis and its elimination by trap passivation in perovskite solar cells provides important directions for future enhancements to device efficiency.

Certified power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have increased to an impressive value of 22.1%. The most efficient perovskite solar cells have the n-i-p device architecture and use 2,2',7,7'-tetrakis(N,N'-di-p-methoxyphenylamine)-9,9'-spirobifluorene (spiro-OMeTAD) as the hole transport material (HTM). However, there exists microscopic inhomogeneity that is detrimental to the long-term performance of the solar cells, primarily as a result of the hygroscopicity of the lithium bis((trifluomethyl)sulfonyl)amide (LiTFSI) dopant. Here, we report a strategy for reducing heterogeneity by using an org.-inorg. integrated hole transport layer (HTL) composed of the soln.-processable conjugated polymer FBT-Th4 and copper oxide (CuxO). The optimized PSCs show significant performance enhancement with power conversion efficiency up to 18.85% from a reverse voltage scan and a stabilized champion efficiency of 18.24% with negligible hysteresis. Moreover, we observe a significant enhancement of the long-term stability of perovskite solar cells under a high humidity of 70-80% in air.

The trap-assisted recombination of electrons and holes in org. semiconductors is investigated. The extd. capture coeffs. of the trap-assisted recombination process are thermally activated with an identical activation energy as measured for the hole mobility μp. We demonstrate that the rate limiting step for this mechanism is the diffusion of free holes towards trapped electrons in their mutual Coulomb field, with the capture coeff. given by (q/[Vegr])μp. As a result, both the bimol. and trap-assisted recombination processes in org. semiconductors are governed by the charge carrier mobilities, allowing predictive modeling of org. light-emitting diodes.

Incorporating n-type fullerene derivs. into the perovskite layer affording bulk heterojunction (BHJ) perovskite solar cells (PSCs) is an effective strategy to passivate trap states, consequently reducing the current-voltage hysteresis and improving the device performance. Herein, we report the synthesis of a novel pyridine-functionalized fullerene deriv. (C60-PyP) via a 1,3-dipolar cycloaddn. reaction, and the unambiguous detn. of its mol. structure by X-ray single crystal diffraction. Upon incorporating C60-PyP as an additive with an optimized doping ratio of 0.13 wt% into the CH3NH3Pbl3 (MAPbI3) perovskite precursor, the regular-structure bulk heterojunction PSC devices exhibit a best power conversion efficiency (PCE) of 19.82%, which is dramatically enhanced relative to that of the control devices (17.61%). The C60-PyP additive provides heterogeneous nucleation sites, leading to the decrease of the nucleation Gibbs free energy and consequently enlarged grain size and improved crystn. of the MAPbI3 perovskite film. Besides, incorporation of C60-PyP results in enhanced cryst. orientation as confirmed by grazing-incidence X-ray diffraction (GIXRD) measurements. Meanwhile, the coordination interaction between the N atom of the pyridine moiety within C60-PyP and the Pb2+ ion within MAPbl3 leads to the passivation of the trap states of the perovskite layer, jointly contributing to the improved device performance and markedly suppressed current-voltage hysteresis. Moreover, the ambient stability of the devices is improved upon C60-PyP incorporation due to the hydrophobic nature of the C60-PyP mol., which presumably resides at the grain boundaries.

Even though org.-inorg. halide perovskite solar cells (PSCs) have rapidly emerged as one of the most promising candidates for photovoltaic applications, simultaneously achieving a controlled microstructure and subdued trap states proved to be challenging. Ammonium benzenesulfonate (ABS) is introduced as a coordination and passivation mol. into a perovskite to improve the film quality and reduce defect densities. ABS can not only form the intermediate phase with precursor materials to decrease the crystn. rate, but also passivate both cationic and anionic defects at grain boundaries due to its zwitterionic structure. The trap d. is significantly reduced, as demonstrated qual. by the confocal photoluminescence (PL) and time-resolved photoluminescence (TRPL) mapping images and quant. by trap d. of states measurement, leading to suppressed trap-induced nonradiative recombination and elongated carrier lifetimes. The highest device efficiency of 20.62% is achieved by the introduction of ABS, mainly originating from the improvement of Voc and FF. The moisture and O tolerance of unencapsulated devices are also enhanced, with only 15% degrdn. of the initial efficiency after storage for 1400 h in an ambient environment with ≈30% humidity. This strategy offers a simple method to fabricate high-quality and low-defect perovskite films, demonstrating the potential of these high-performance PSCs for large-scale prodn.

Anionic and cationic defects are considered as one of the crucial factors that affect carrier transport property and degrdn. of perovskite photovoltaic materials. Herein, a simple passivation is demonstrated of hot casted perovskite film in air by a dipolar ion, 2-thiophene ethylammonium chloride (TEACl), showing enhanced power conversion efficiency (PCE) of solar cell from 15.44-18.84% with increased open circuit voltage (Voc) by 50 mV. The dipolar ion of TEACl can simultaneously passivate both cationic and anionic defects. Space charge limited current model, Urbach energy anal., and photoluminescence spectroscopy were conducted and revealed that the defects passivated by TEACl reduced the defects d. of perovskite films, nonradiative recombination, and electronic disorder. In addn., the device with TEACl passivation exhibited outstanding stability of power output (< 0.1% decay) as compared with the device without passivation (> 8% decay) from the 300 s measurement of current verse time plots (J-T plots) at 65% relative humidity and 50° in air. The 80% of initial PCE was maintained after 700 h storage. As compared to conventional passivation approaches which are typically carried out at complicated crystn. step of perovskite, this post-treatment process can be easily done on the crystd. perovskite film. This facile approach is upscale and compatible with conventional coating techniques such as slot-die coating, spray, etc. for high-quality perovskite film.

Broadening the absorption bandwidth of polymer solar cells by incorporating multiple absorber donors into the bulk-heterojunction active layer is an attractive means of resolving the narrow absorption of org. semiconductors. However, this leads to a much more complicated system, and previous efforts have met with only limited success. Here, several dual-donor and multi-donor bulk-heterojunction polymer solar cells based on a pool of materials with different absorption ranges and preferred mol. structures were studied. The study shows clearly that compatible polymer donors can coexist harmoniously, but the mixing of incompatible polymers can lead to severe mol. disorder and limit device performance. These results provide guidance for the general use of multiple-donor bulk heterojunctions to overcome the absorption limitation and achieve both high performance and fabrication simplicity for org. solar cells.

We describe a facile method to fabricate high quality CH3NH3PbI3 films with smooth surface and without residual PbI2 through mol. exchange, rather than ionic intercalation. It forms a Lewis acid-base adduct of PbI2·xDMF when PbI2 ppts. from DMF soln. The lattice of PbI2 is expanded more than 30% due to the intercalation of DMF. With the lattice expansion, CH3NH3I (MAI) diffuses into the PbI2·xDMF lattice easily, and the PbI2·xDMF converts completely to CH3NH3PI3 by mol. exchange between DMF and MAI. The lattice vol. changes little during the mol. exchange in PbI2·xDMF. Thus, it is easy to fabricate high quality perovskite films from the Lewis adduct of PbI2·xDMF. The perovskite solar cells fabricated from the Lewis adduct exhibit higher photovoltaic performance than those from the PbI2 films. This work reveals the important role of common solvent in controlling the quality of perovskite films.

Since the 1st report on the long-term durable 9.7% solid-state perovskite solar cell employing methylammonium lead iodide (MeNH3PbI3), mesoporous TiO2, and 2,2',7,7'-tetrakis[N,N-di(4-methoxyphenyl)amino]-9,9'-spirobifluorene (spiro-MeOTAD) in 2012, following the seed technologies on perovskite-sensitized liq. junction solar cells in 2009 and 2011, a surge of interest was focused on perovskite solar cells due to superb photovoltaic performance and extremely facile fabrication processes. The power conversion efficiency (PCE) of perovskite solar cells reached 21% in a very short period of time. Such an unprecedentedly high photovoltaic performance is due to the intrinsic optoelectronic property of organolead iodide perovskite material. Also, a high dielec. const., sub-millimeter scale carrier diffusion length, an underlying ferroelec. property, and ion migration behavior can make organolead halide perovskites suitable for multi-functionality. Thus, besides solar cell applications, perovskite material has recently been applied to a variety fields of materials science such as photodetectors, light emitting diodes, lasing, x-ray imaging, resistive memory, and H2O splitting. Regardless of application areas, the growth of a well-defined perovskite layer with high crystallinity is essential for effective use of its excellent physicochem. properties. Therefore, an effective methodol. for prepn. of high quality perovskite layers is required. In this Account, an effective methodol. for prodn. of high quality perovskite layers is described, which is the Lewis acid-base adduct approach. In the soln. process to form the perovskite layer, the key chems. of MeNH3I (or HC(NH2)2I) and PbI2 are used by dissolving them in polar aprotic solvents. Since polar aprotic solvents bear O, S, or N, they can act as a Lewis base. The main group compd. PbI2 is known to be a Lewis acid. Thus, PbI2 has a chance to form an adduct by reacting with the Lewis base. Crystal growth and morphol. of perovskite can be controlled by taking advantage of the weak chem. interaction in the adduct. The authors have successfully fabricated highly reproducible MeNH3PbI3 perovskite solar cells with PCE ≤19.7% via adducts of PbI2 with O-donor N,N'-DMSO. This adduct approach is generally adopted, where formamidinium lead iodide perovskite, HC(NH2)2PbI3 (FAPbI3), with large grain, high crystallinity, and long-lived carrier lifetime was successfully fabricated via an adduct of PbI2 with S-donor thiourea as Lewis base. The adduct approach proposed in this Account is a very promising methodol. to achieve high quality perovskite films with high photovoltaic performance. Also, single crystal growth on the conductive substrate is expected to be possible if the authors kinetically control the elimination of Lewis base in the adduct.

Certified power conversion efficiencies (PCEs) of perovskite solar cells have increased to reach an impressive 22.1%. However, there exists microscopic inhomogeneity that limits high PCE, primarily as a result of defects at grain interiors and boundaries of perovskite films. Here, we report a strategy for reducing heterogeneity by using a bifunctional non-volatile Lewis base additive urea. The addn. of 4 mol % urea results in significant enhancement of the macroscopic photoluminescence lifetime from 200.5 to 752.4 ns and elimination of trap-mediated non-radiative recombination, resulting in an improved PCE. The Lewis base urea is found to interact with soln. precursors to retard crystal growth and enhance crystallinity, which subsequently ppts. at grain boundaries to passivate defects after completion of crystal growth. The resulting perovskite films show superior homogeneity in cond. at both grain interior and boundaries in comparison with the bare perovskite films.

To increase the com. prospects of metal halide perovskite solar cells, there is a need for simple, cost-effective, and generalized approaches that mitigate their intrinsic thermal instability. Here we show that 1,3,7-trimethylxanthine, a commodity chem. with two conjugated carboxyl groups better known by its common name caffeine, improves the performance and thermal stability of perovskite solar cells based on both MAPbI3 and CsFAMAPbI3 active layers. The strong interaction between caffeine and Pb2+ ions serves as a "mol. lock" that increases the activation energy during film crystn., delivering a perovskite film with preferred orientation, improved electronic properties, reduced ion migration, and greatly enhanced thermal stability. Planar n-i-p solar cells based on caffeine-incorporated pure MAPbI3 perovskites, which are notoriously unstable, exhibit a champion-stabilized efficiency of 19.8% and retain over 85% of their efficiency under continuous annealing at 85°C in nitrogen.

On a planar substrate the sequential deposition of CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite is optimized by retarding the crystn. of PbI2. This strategy overcomes the problem of incomplete conversion and uncontrolled particle sizes of perovskite in the absence of mesoporous scaffolds, greatly increasing the film reproducibility. Highly efficient and reproducible planar-structured perovskite solar cells were obtained with the best efficiency of 13.5%, av. efficiency of 12.5% and a small std. deviation of 0.57 from a total of 120 cells.

Perovskite solar cells are a highly competitive candidate for next-generation photovoltaic technol. Defects in the perovskite grain boundaries and on the film surfaces however have significant impacts on both the device efficiency and environmental stability. Herein, a strategy using org. dyes as additives to passivate the defect states and produce more n-type perovskite films, thereby improving charge transport and decreasing charge recombination, is reported. Based on this strategy, the power conversion efficiency of the perovskite solar cell is significantly increased from 18.13% to 20.18% with a negligible hysteresis. Furthermore, the rich hydrogen bonds and carbonyl structures in the org. dye can significantly enhance device stability both in terms of humidity and thermal stress. The results present a promising pathway using abundant and colorful org. dyes as additives to achieve high-performance perovskite solar cells.

CH3NH3PbI3-xClx is a commonly used chem. formula to represent the methylammonium lead halide perovskite fabricated from mixed Cl- and I-contg. salt precursors. Despite the rapid progress in improving its photovoltaic efficiency, fundamental questions remain regarding the at. ratio of Cl in the perovskite as well as the reaction mechanism that leads to its formation and crystn. The authors studied these questions through a combination of chem., morphol., structural and thermal characterizations. The elemental analyses reveal unambiguously the negligible amt. of Cl atoms in the CH3NH3PbI3-xClx perovskite. By studying the thermal characteristics of methylammonium halides as well as the annealing process in a polymer/perovskite/FTO glass structure, the formation of the CH3NH3PbI3-xClx perovskite is likely driven by release of gaseous CH3NH3Cl (or other org. chlorides) through an intermediate organometal mixed halide phase. Also, the comparative study on CH3NH3I /PbCl2 and CH3NH3I/PbI2 precursor combinations with different molar ratios suggest that the initial introduction of a CH3NH3+ rich environment is crit. to slow down the perovskite formation process and thus improve the growth of the crystal domains during annealing; accordingly, the function of Cl- is to facilitate the release of excess CH3NH3+ at a relatively low annealing temps.

CH3NH3PbI3-xClx perovskites enable fabrication of highly efficient solar cells. Chloride ions benefit the morphol., carrier diffusion length, and stability of perovskite films; however, whether those benefits stem from the presence of Cl- in the precursor soln. or from their incorporation in annealed films is debated. The photothermal-induced resonance, an in situ technique with nanoscale resoln., is leveraged to measure the bandgap of CH3NH3PbI3-xClx films obtained by a multicycle coating process that produces high efficiency (∼16%) solar cells. Because chloride ions modify the perovskite lattice, thereby widening the bandgap, measuring the bandgap locally yields the local chloride content. After a mild annealing (60 min, 60°) the films consist of Cl-rich (x < 0.3) and Cl-poor phases that upon further annealing (110°) evolve into a homogeneous Cl-poorer (x < 0.06) phase, suggesting that methylammonium-chloride is progressively expelled from the film. Despite the small chloride content, CH3NH3PbI3-xClx films show better thermal stability up to 140° with respect CH3NH3PbI3 films fabricated with the same methodol.

The HC(NH2)2+(FA+) is a well-known substitute to CH3NH3+(MA+) for its capability to extend light utilization for improved power conversion efficiency for perovskite solar cells; unfortunately, the dark cubic phase (α-phase) can easily transition to the yellow orthorhombic phase (δ-phase) at room temp., an issue that prevents its com. application. In this report, an inorg. material (NbF5) is developed to stabilize the desired α-phase perovskite material by incorporating NbF5 additive into the perovskite films. It is found that the NbF5 additive effectively suppresses the formation of the yellow δ-phase in the perovskite synthesis and aging process, thus enhancing the humidity and light-soaking stability of the perovskite film. As a result, the perovskite solar cells with the NbF5 additive exhibit improved air stability by tenfold, retaining nearly 80% of their initial efficiency after aging in air for 50 d. In addn., under full-sun AM 1.5 G illumination of a xenon lamp without any UV-redn., the perovskite solar cells with the NbF5 additive also show fivefold improved illumination stability than the control devices without NbF5.

Procedures for testing org. solar cell devices and modules with respect to stability and operational lifetime are described. The descriptions represent a consensus of the discussion and conclusions reached during the first 3 years of the international summit on OPV stability (ISOS). The procedures include directions for shelf life testing, outdoor testing, lab. weathering testing and thermal cycling testing, as well as guidelines for reporting data. These procedures are not meant to be qualification tests, but rather generally agreed test conditions and practices to allow ready comparison between labs. and to help improving the reliability of reported values. Failure mechanisms and detailed degrdn. mechanisms are not covered in this report.

The energy costs assocd. with sepg. tightly bound excitons (photoinduced electron-hole pairs) and extg. free charges from highly disordered low-mobility networks represent fundamental losses for many low-cost photovoltaic technologies. A low-cost, soln.-processable solar cell is reported, based on a highly cryst. perovskite absorber with intense visible to near-IR absorptivity, that has a power conversion efficiency of 10.9% in a single-junction device under simulated full sunlight. This "meso-superstructured solar cell" exhibits exceptionally few fundamental energy losses; it can generate open-circuit photovoltages of more than 1.1 V, despite the relatively narrow absorber band gap of 1.55 eV. The functionality arises from the use of mesoporous alumina as an inert scaffold that structures the absorber and forces electrons to reside in and be transported through the perovskite.

The band gap of formamidinium lead iodide (FAPbI3) perovskites allows broader absorption of the solar spectrum relative to conventional methylammonium lead iodide (MAPbI3). Because the optoelectronic properties of perovskite films are closely related to film quality, deposition of dense and uniform films is crucial for fabricating high-performance perovskite solar cells (PSCs). An approach is reported for depositing high-quality FAPbI3 films, involving FAPbI3 crystn. by the direct intramol. exchange of dimethylsulfoxide (DMSO) mols. intercalated in PbI2 with formamidinium iodide. This process produces FAPbI3 films with (111)-preferred crystallog. orientation, large-grained dense microstructures, and flat surfaces without residual PbI2. Using films prepd. by this technique, the FAPbI3-based PSCs are fabricated with max. power conversion efficiency greater than 20%.

Here, first-principles d. functional theory calcns. are presented which reveal how water incorporation in hybrid halide perovskite [CH3NH3]PbI3 (MAPbI3) catalyzes the phase transition to the ([CH3NH3]PbI3.H2O edge-sharing) monohydrate (colorless) phase, eliminating its favorable photovoltaic properties. First, fundamental chem. and electrostatic interactions between water and each component of MAPbI3 are analyzed, demonstrating their dependence on water concn. Second, the energetics of incorporated water is explored, leading to the discovery of spontaneous phase segregation into dry regions and regions with more than one water per formula unit-termed the "super-hydrous state.". Third, the properties of the super-hydrous state are analyzed, including the acceleration of octahedron breaking and rearrangement by the high water d. This reveals the phase transformation to be a bulk process, initiated at the super-hydrous regions. This paper concludes with a discussion of how this super-hydrous model explains disparate recent exptl. observations concerning the water-induced transition from (black) perovskite to edge-sharing PbI2 (yellow) phase. Towards increasing the stability of perovskite solar cells, the addn. of Cs+ is found to be a rational approach. Recently triple cation based perovskite solar cells were found to be more effective in terms of stability and efficiency. Heretofore they were unexplored, so the Cs/MA/FA (cesium/methyl ammonium/formamidinium) cation based perovskites is probed by XPS and correlated their compositional features with their solar cell performances. The Cs+ content was found to be optimum at 5%, when incorporated in the (MA0.15FA0.85)Pb(I0.85Br0.15)3 lattice, because the corresponding device yielded the highest fill factor compared to the perovskite without Cs+ and with 10% Cs+. XPS studies distinctly reveal how Cs+ aids in maintaining the expected stoichiometric ratios of I:Pb2+, I:N and Br:Pb2+ in the perovskites, and how the valence band (VB) edge is dependent on the Cs+ proportion, which in turn governs the open circuit voltage. Even at a low content of 5%, Cs+ resides deep within the absorber layer, and ensures min. distortion of the VB level (compared to 0% and 10% Cs+ perovskites) upon Ar+ sputtering, thus allowing the formation of a stable robust material that delivers excellent solar cell response. This study which brings out the role of Cs+ is anticipated to be of paramount significance to further engineer the compn. and improve device performances.

Long, balanced electron and hole diffusion lengths greater than 100 nm in the polycryst. organolead trihalide compd. CH3NH3PbI3 are crit. for highly efficient perovskite solar cells. We found that the diffusion lengths in CH3NH3PbI3 single crystals grown by a soln.-growth method can exceed 175 μm under 1 sun (100 mW cm-2) illumination and exceed 3 mm under weak light for both electrons and holes. The internal quantum efficiencies approach 100% in 3-mm-thick single-crystal perovskite solar cells under weak light. These long diffusion lengths result from greater carrier mobility, longer lifetime, and much smaller trap densities in the single crystals than in polycryst. thin films. The long carrier diffusion lengths enabled the use of CH3NH3PbI3 in radiation sensing and energy harvesting through the gammavoltaic effect, with an efficiency of 3.9% measured with an intense cesium-137 source.

The soln. processing of polycryst. perovskite films introduces trap states that can adversely affect their optoelectronic properties. Motivated by the use of small-mol. surfactants to improve the optoelectronic performance of perovskites, we demonstrate the use of polymerswith coordinating groups to improve the performance of solutionprocessed semiconductor films. The use of these polymer modifiers results in amarked change in the electronic properties of the films, asmeasured by both carrier dynamics and overall device performance. The devices grown with the polymer poly(4-vinylpyridine) (PVP) show significantly enhanced power conversion efficiency from 16.9 ± 0.7% to 18.8 ± 0.8% (champion efficiency, 20.2%) from a reverse scan and stabilized champion efficiency from 17.5 to 19.1% [under a bias of 0.94 V and AM (air mass) 1.5-G, 1-sun illumination over 30 min] compared to controls without any passivation. Treating the perovskite filmwith PVP enables a VOC of up to 1.16 V,which is among the best reported for a CH3NH3PbI3 perovskite solar cell and one of the lowest voltage deficits reported for any perovskite to date. In addn., perovskite solar cells treated with PVP show a long shelf lifetime of up to 90 days (retaining 85% of the initial efficiency) and increased by a factor of more than 20 compared to those without any polymer (degrading to 85% after ∼4 days). Our work opens up a new class of chem. additives for improving perovskite performance and should pave the way toward improving perovskite solar cells for high efficiency and stability.

We study the effects of a series of post-deposition ligand treatments on the photoluminescence (PL) of polycryst. methylammonium lead triiodide perovskite thin films. We show that a variety of Lewis bases can improve the bulk PL quantum efficiency (PLQE) and extend the av. PL lifetime, 〈τ〉, with large enhancements concd. at grain boundaries. Notably, we demonstrate thin-film PLQE as high as 35 ± 1% and 〈τ〉 as long as 8.82 ± 0.03 μs at solar equiv. carrier densities using tri-n-octylphosphine oxide-treated films. Using glow discharge optical emission spectroscopy and NMR spectroscopy, we show that the ligands are incorporated primarily at the film surface and are acting as electron donors. These results indicate it is possible to obtain thin-film PL lifetime and PLQE values that are comparable to those from single crystals by control over surface chem.
